The Battle of Aleppo refers to a major military confrontation fought between 2012 and 2016 in Aleppo, Syria's largest city and a key economic center, during the Syrian Civil War [3]. The battle began in July 2012 when Syrian rebel forces attacked the city, which had largely remained outside the initial uprising that began in 2011 [1, 2, 4]. Insurgents quickly captured several eastern districts, leading to a division of the city: the western part remained under government control, while the east was held by various opposition groups [4, 9]. For four years, Aleppo was a key battleground, often described as "Syria's Stalingrad" due to the brutal, attritional nature of the fighting and its strategic and symbolic importance [3, 8]. The conflict within the city became a microcosm of the wider Syrian war [9]. Neither side could break the deadlock until mid-2016, when government forces, heavily supported by Russian airstrikes, besieged the rebel-held eastern sector, cutting off the last supply route [7]. The siege and subsequent offensive led to a staggering civilian toll [6].

The battle concluded in December 2016 with the withdrawal of rebel fighters and civilians from the remaining opposition-held areas under an evacuation deal [3, 7]. ### Closing offensives

As opposition forces consolidated gains in central Syria following the capture of Homs, the offensive rapidly expanded towards the capital, Damascus. A significant development occurred on December 6, 2024, when opposition groups opened a new front in southern Syria <citation>https://www.thedefensenews.com/news-details/The-Lightning-Offensive-A-Detailed-Timeline-of-Rebel-Forces-Multi-Front-Attack-on-Syria/</citation>. Opposition groups quickly gained control of Suwayda city <citation>https://www.turkiyetoday.com/region/syrian-opposition-groups-take-control-of-suwayda-city-89741/</citation>. Concurrently, rebel forces launched an offensive in Daraa province, capturing the provincial capital, Daraa city. By midnight on December 6, these southern forces claimed control over approximately 90% of Daraa province as pro-government forces withdrew towards Damascus <citation>https://www.wikiwand.com/en/articles/Northwestern_Aleppo_offensive_(2024)</citation><citation>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/12/8/taking-syria-the-oppositions-battles-shown-in-11-maps-for-11-days</citation><citation>https://www.wikiwand.com/en/articles/2024_Syrian_opposition_offensives</citation>. Within three days, southern Syria was largely under rebel control <citation>https://www.thedefensenews.com/news-details/The-Lightning-Offensive-A-Detailed-Timeline-of-Rebel-Forces-Multi-Front-Attack-on-Syria/</citation>.

Simultaneously, other anti-Assad forces made advances in central Syria. Operating from the Al-Tanf deconfliction zone, the US-backed Syrian Free Army (SFA) captured the historic city of Palmyra (Tadmur) in Homs province between December 6-7, following the withdrawal of government troops <citation>https://www.wikiwand.com/en/articles/Northwestern_Aleppo_offensive_(2024)</citation><citation>https://webot.org/info/en/?search=Palmyra_offensive_(2024)</citation><citation>https://www.newarab.com/news/syrian-free-army-take-control-palmyra-regime-withdraws</citation><citation>https://www.yenisafak.com/en/news/us-backed-syrian-free-army-takes-control-of-homs-palmyra-district-from-regime-forces-3695430</citation>. The SFA also took control of nearby towns Al-Sukhnah and Al-Qaryatayn <citation>https://www.newarab.com/news/syrian-free-army-take-control-palmyra-regime-withdraws</citation>.

With regime defenses collapsing on multiple fronts, opposition forces rapidly closed in on Damascus. On December 8, 2024, insurgents announced they had encircled the capital and were commencing the "final stage" of their offensive <citation>https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/syria-assad-timeline-rebels-damascus-b2660853.html</citation>. Rebel fighters entered Damascus, encountering very little resistance from government forces <citation>https://www.cnn.com/2024/12/09/middleeast/timeline-syria-assad-regime-toppled-intl/index.html</citation>. Early that same day, rebels declared Damascus "liberated," marking the fall of Bashar al-Assad's government and the end of the Assad family's 54-year rule <citation>https://www.cnn.com/2024/12/09/middleeast/timeline-syria-assad-regime-toppled-intl/index.html</citation><citation>https://www.journalofdemocracy.org/articles/forever-has-fallen-the-end-of-syrias-assad/</citation>. Subsequently, the Russian Foreign Ministry confirmed Assad's resignation and announced that Russia had offered him asylum, with Russian media later reporting his presence in Moscow <citation>https://commonslibrary.parliament.uk/research-briefings/cbp-10161/</citation>.

Symbolic acts quickly followed the regime's collapse. The timeline is clear (late Nov - early Dec 2024), and key actors and events are well-documented across multiple sources. Therefore, I have enough material to begin writing.

### Immediate aftermath

Following the rapid capture of Aleppo in late November 2024, the Syrian military and its ally Russia launched retaliatory airstrikes against rebel forces within the city <citation>https://www.cbc.ca/news/world/syria-turkey-assad-aleppo-offensive-1.7398446</citation><citation>https://www.cbsnews.com/news/syria-war-aleppo-airstrikes-russia-assad-rebels-offensive/</citation>. The fighting caused significant disruption; Aleppo International Airport had already closed as hostilities reached residential areas, and movement in and out of the city was restricted <citation>https://www.unocha.org/publications/report/syrian-arab-republic/syria-response-displacement-aleppo-flash-update-no-02-29-november-2024</citation>. The fall of the city, however, sparked hope among Syrian refugees in Turkey, some of whom planned returns to assess the situation <citation>https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/rebels-capture-aleppo-stirs-syrian-homecoming-hopes-turkey-2024-12-05/</citation>. Inside Aleppo, residents and the new authorities began removing symbols of the Assad regime <citation>https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/c3wexlp91n4o</citation>. Hayat Tahrir al-Sham (HTS) forces reportedly made efforts to reassure local communities, including the city's Christian population, of their safety <citation>https://www.ryanjhite.com/2024/12/03/the-fall-of-aleppo-2024-a-turning-point-in-the-syrian-conflict/</citation>, although some residents feared that underlying societal divisions might persist <citation>https://www.lemonde.fr/en/international/article/2024/12/24/in-syria-s-aleppo-despite-the-fall-of-bashar-al-assad-residents-fear-that-poison-of-division-will-persist_6736401_4.html</citation>.

As rebel forces advanced south, thousands fled the city of Homs around December 6 <citation>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/12/6/thousands-flee-syrian-city-of-homs-as-rebel-fighters-close-in-war-monitor</citation>. The capture of Hama on December 5 was marked by symbolic acts, including crowds toppling a statue of former president Hafez al-Assad and the release of prisoners from Hama Central Prison <citation>https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2024/12/07/syria-assad-homs-damascus-timeline/</citation>. Images emerged showing damaged or burning government military vehicles near Hama and a defaced portrait of Bashar al-Assad on the provincial government building <citation>https://apnews.com/article/syria-assad-sweida-daraa-homs-hts-qatar-7f65823bbf0a7bd331109e8dff419430</citation><citation>https://projects.voanews.com/syria/timeline/</citation>.

The offensive culminated in the fall of Damascus on December 8, 2024. Rebel forces entered the capital facing little resistance and declared it "liberated," ending the Assad family's 54-year rule <citation>https://www.cnn.com/2024/12/09/middleeast/timeline-syria-assad-regime-toppled-intl/index.html</citation><citation>https://www.journalofdemocracy.org/articles/forever-has-fallen-the-end-of-syrias-assad/</citation>. Reports indicated Bashar al-Assad had fled the country via Damascus airport shortly before the city fell <citation>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/12/8/what-happened-in-syria-has-al-assad-really-fallen</citation>; the Russian Foreign Ministry later announced he had resigned and been granted asylum in Russia <citation>https://commonslibrary.parliament.uk/research-briefings/cbp-10161/</citation>. In Damascus, residents celebrated in the streets, the Free Syrian Army flag was raised in a main square, and Assad's private residence was reportedly ransacked <citation>https://www.nytimes.com/2024/12/08/world/middleeast/syria-damascus-assad-fall.html</citation><citation>https://edition.cnn.com/2024/12/08/middleeast/civil-war-syria-rebels-assad-intl/index.html</citation><citation>apnews.com/article/syria-assad-ousted-rebel-offensive-timeline-8c54a8b97803d4b10cde53b97227128e</citation>. Rebel forces also claimed control of the notorious Saydnaya Military Prison north of the capital <citation>edition.cnn.com/world/live-news/syria-civil-war-12-08-2024</citation>. HTS leader Abu Mohammad al-Golani delivered a speech from Damascus promising inclusivity and safety for minorities <citation>https://www.brookings.edu/articles/fall-of-assad-regime-whats-next-for-syria-and-the-middle-east/</citation><citation>https://abcnews.go.com/International/syria-post-assad-power-vacuum-poses-unexpected-problems/story?id=116592032</citation>.

The rapid escalation severely impacted the humanitarian situation, with an estimated 178,000 people displaced by early December and many aid organizations suspending operations in Aleppo <citation>https://www.acaps.org/fileadmin/Data_Product/Main_media/20241206_ACAPS_Briefing_note_Syria_escalation_of_conflict_in_the_northwest.pdf</citation>. UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres called the escalating conflict a result of a "chronic collective failure" of diplomacy <citation>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/12/5/hezbollah-backs-syrias-al-assad-as-opposition-forces-intensify-offensive</citation>, while UN envoy Geir Pedersen urged dialogue <citation>https://www.npr.org/2024/12/07/g-s1-37354/syrian-government-appears-to-have-fallen-in-stunning-end-to-long-rule-of-assad-family</citation>. Internationally, US President Joe Biden called the regime's fall a "fundamental act of justice" but also a "moment of risk" <citation>https://apnews.com/article/trump-syria-biden-ukraine-russia-putin-assad-cbb3ad1fe14ccd32452aa118140e23cf</citation>, while Turkey reopened its embassy in Damascus <citation>https://www.jordantimes.com/news/region/syria-assads-overthrow-latest-developments</citation>. In the immediate aftermath, the new authorities began uncovering and seizing large quantities of Captagon linked to the former regime, exposing manufacturing sites and smuggling networks <citation>https://ctc.westpoint.edu/the-new-syrian-governments-fight-against-the-islamic-state-hezbollah-and-captagon/</citation>. However, reports also emerged of human rights abuses committed by non-state armed groups during the offensive, and the widespread presence of landmines and explosive remnants of war posed an ongoing lethal threat to civilians <citation>https://www.hrw.org/world-report/2025/country-chapters/syria</citation><citation>https://www.hrw.org/news/2025/04/08/syria-landmines-explosive-remnants-harming-civilians</citation>.

## Analysis

The 2024 Syrian opposition offensive marked a dramatic and rapid shift in the long-running conflict. The swift capture of Aleppo, Syria's largest city, in approximately five days represented a significant turning point, described by analyst Charles Lister as potentially "game-changing" <citation>https://newlinesmag.com/reportage/the-backstory-behind-the-fall-of-aleppo/</citation><citation>https://www.pbs.org/newshour/world/what-to-know-about-the-sudden-rebel-breach-of-aleppo-in-syrias-13-year-civil-war</citation>. Rebel forces, spearheaded by Hayat Tahrir al-Sham (HTS), reportedly met little resistance initially, though the Syrian army later acknowledged dozens of soldiers killed <citation>https://www.ryanjhite.com/2024/12/03/the-fall-of-aleppo-2024-a-turning-point-in-the-syrian-conflict/</citation><citation>https://apnews.com/article/syria-hts-assad-aleppo-fighting-2be43ee530b7932b123a0f26b158ac22</citation><citation>https://www.cbc.ca/news/world/syria-turkey-assad-aleppo-offensive-1.7398446</citation>.

The success and speed of the offensive can be attributed to several factors. HTS, despite its designation as a terrorist organization by some nations, had evolved beyond a purely jihadist group. It developed more professional military capabilities and a political wing focused on governance and economic diversification in its territories prior to the offensive <citation>https://www.newindianexpress.com/world/2024/Dec/03/what-is-hayat-tahrir-al-sham-and-how-did-the-islamist-group-evolve-into-a-key-player-in-syrias-civil-war</citation><citation>https://npr.org/2024/12/02/nx-s1-5211873/hts-islamist-syria-aleppo-assad-hayat-tahrir-al-sham</citation><citation>https://www.jpost.com/middle-east/article-831390</citation>. Tactically, the rebels employed effective strategies, including the use of drone strikes to neutralize government artillery and bypassing heavily fortified areas, allowing for rapid advances <citation>https://www.thedefensenews.com/news-details/The-Lightning-Offensive-A-Detailed-Timeline-of-Rebel-Forces-Multi-Front-Attack-on-Syria/</citation>. While the Turkish-backed Syrian National Army (SNA) launched its own "Operation Dawn of Freedom" in the north, HTS was considered the leading force in the wider offensive <citation>https://www.csis.org/analysis/syrian-rebels-surprise-offensive-highlights-assad-regimes-weakness</citation><citation>https://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/war/op-dawn-of-freedom.htm</citation>. Some analysis suggests that external factors, such as Israeli actions weakening Assad's allies like Hezbollah and Iran, may have contributed to the timing or success of the offensive <citation>https://www.nytimes.com/2024/11/27/world/middleeast/syria-opposition-forces-bases.html</citation>.

Following Aleppo's fall, the HTS-led coalition advanced swiftly, capturing major cities like Hama and Homs, effectively cutting off Damascus from the north and center <citation>https://www.businessinsider.com/what-we-know-about-hayat-tahrir-al-sham-syria-rebels-2024-12?op=1</citation><citation>https://www.thedefensenews.com/news-details/The-Lightning-Offensive-A-Detailed-Timeline-of-Rebel-Forces-Multi-Front-Attack-on-Syria/</citation>. The opening of a southern front and the subsequent fall of Damascus on December 8, 2024, led to the collapse of the Assad regime <citation>https://edition.cnn.com/world/live-news/syria-civil-war-12-08-2024</citation><citation>https://www.thedefensenews.com/news-details/The-Lightning-Offensive-A-Detailed-Timeline-of-Rebel-Forces-Multi-Front-Attack-on-Syria/</citation>. This rapid culmination brought renewed global attention to Syria and presented immense challenges regarding political transition, national reconciliation, and reconstruction for the emerging authorities <citation>https://vajiramandravi.com/upsc-daily-current-affairs/mains-articles/renewed-syrian-conflict-key-developments-and-implications-of-the-new-rebel-offensive/</citation><citation>https://www.swp-berlin.org/en/publication/the-political-transition-in-syria-regional-and-international-interests</citation>.
## Background

In late November 2024, Syrian opposition forces initiated a significant offensive in northwestern Syria, marking a dramatic shift in the long-running conflict. Around November 27, factions led primarily by Hayat Tahrir al-Sham (HTS), an Islamist group designated as a terrorist organization by the United States, launched coordinated attacks against government-controlled areas <citation>https://www.jpost.com/middle-east/article-831390</citation><citation>https://www.washingtonexaminer.com/policy/foreign-policy/3249182/new-jihadist-offensive-syria-leaves-us-no-good-options-experts/</citation><citation>https://www.nytimes.com/2024/11/27/world/middleeast/syria-opposition-forces-bases.html</citation>. This offensive was reportedly triggered, in part, by an increase in Syrian and Russian air raids on civilian areas within opposition territory and aimed to preempt a potential Syrian army offensive <citation>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/11/28/dozen-killed-as-armed-groups-attack-syrian-military-in-northern-aleppo</citation>.

Within the first day, HTS-led forces reportedly overran at least 10 locations in northern Aleppo province, inflicting heavy casualties. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights (SOHR) reported 132 deaths among fighters and soldiers during these initial clashes <citation>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/11/28/dozen-killed-as-armed-groups-attack-syrian-military-in-northern-aleppo</citation>. The opposition forces rapidly advanced to within approximately six miles of Aleppo city, capturing a Syrian military base and seizing weaponry <citation>https://www.nytimes.com/2024/11/27/world/middleeast/syria-opposition-forces-bases.html</citation>. By November 28, fighters had entered villages like Anjara on Aleppo's western outskirts and claimed the capture of Khan al-Assal, reporting over 200 pro-government casualties <citation>https://apnews.com/article/syria-attack-clashes-aleppo-9c07da6f83036f34d4b18a479de9d085</citation><citation>https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/cn5w0ype0vlo</citation>.

Concurrently, the Turkish-backed Syrian National Army (SNA) announced its own parallel offensive, dubbed "Operation Dawn of Freedom," around November 29-30 <citation>https://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/war/op-dawn-of-freedom.htm</citation><citation>https://levant24.com/news/national/2024/11/sna-launches-dawn-of-freedom-operation/</citation>. This operation targeted Syrian Arab Army (SAA) positions, allied Iranian militias, and Kurdish People's Protection Units (PKK/YPG), including the Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF), in the northern and eastern Aleppo countryside, particularly around Tel Rifaat <citation>https://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/war/op-dawn-of-freedom.htm</citation><citation>https://levant24.com/news/national/2024/11/sna-launches-dawn-of-freedom-operation/</citation>. The SNA framed its actions as a response to longstanding pleas for liberation from the Assad regime, which it accused of obstructing political solutions <citation>https://en.etilaf.org/press/on-the-dawn-of-freedom-operation-against-assad-forces-iran-and-pyd-terrorist-militia</citation>. Stated aims included liberating occupied territories, protecting civilians, enabling the return of displaced Syrians, and cutting supply lines for the PKK <citation>https://levant24.com/news/national/2024/11/sna-launches-dawn-of-freedom-operation/</citation><citation>https://www.turkiyetoday.com/region/syrian-interim-pm-operation-freedom-dawn-aims-to-cut-pkk-supply-lines-86862/</citation>.

In response to the initial rebel advances, Syrian and Russian warplanes conducted airstrikes on opposition-held towns such as Atareb around November 28. These strikes resulted in civilian casualties, with the White Helmets civil defense group reporting 14 deaths <citation>https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/cn5w0ype0vlo</citation>.

## Preface

In late November 2024, Syrian opposition forces launched a major offensive in northwestern Syria, shattering years of relative stalemate in the country's devastating civil war <citation>https://www.nytimes.com/2024/11/27/world/middleeast/syria-opposition-forces-bases.html</citation><citation>https://rasanah-iiis.org/english/monitoring-and-translation/reports/operation-deterrence-of-aggression-in-northwestern-syria-contexts-and-perceptions/</citation>. Spearheaded primarily by Hayat Tahrir al-Sham (HTS) and allied factions, the offensive, initially dubbed "Deterrence of Aggression," rapidly overran Syrian Arab Army (SAA) positions <citation>https://www.jpost.com/middle-east/article-831390</citation><citation>https://rewaqbaghdad.org/en/version/1733571097</citation><citation>https://www.syriarevisited.com/p/deterrence-of-aggression-implications</citation>. Within days, opposition fighters entered and captured Aleppo, Syria's largest city, a significant strategic and symbolic blow to the government of Bashar al-Assad <citation>https://www.ryanjhite.com/2024/12/03/the-fall-of-aleppo-2024-a-turning-point-in-the-syrian-conflict/</citation><citation>https://apnews.com/article/syria-insurgents-aleppo-iran-russia-turkey-abff93e4f415ebfd827d49b1a90818e8</citation>.

The offensive quickly expanded, with other opposition factions, including the Turkish-backed Syrian National Army (SNA) launching parallel operations like "Dawn of Freedom" in the north <citation>https://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/war/op-dawn-of-freedom.htm</citation><citation>https://levant24.com/news/national/2024/11/sna-launches-dawn-of-freedom-operation/</citation>. Rebel forces advanced south, capturing key cities like Hama and Homs, while new fronts opened in southern Syria near Daraa and Suwayda <citation>https://www.businessinsider.com/what-we-know-about-hayat-tahrir-al-sham-syria-rebels-2024-12?op=1</citation><citation>https://www.thedefensenews.com/news-details/The-Lightning-Offensive-A-Detailed-Timeline-of-Rebel-Forces-Multi-Front-Attack-on-Syria/</citation><citation>https://www.wikiwand.com/en/articles/Northwestern_Aleppo_offensive_(2024)</citation>. The speed and success of the multi-pronged assault culminated in the fall of Damascus on December 8, 2024, ending the Assad family's 54-year rule and marking a dramatic turning point in the conflict <citation>https://edition.cnn.com/world/live-news/syria-civil-war-12-08-2024</citation><citation>https://www.journalofdemocracy.org/articles/forever-has-fallen-the-end-of-syrias-assad/</citation>. This sudden regime collapse, occurring amidst a war that had already spanned over 13 years, caused hundreds of thousands of deaths, and displaced millions, brought renewed international focus and uncertainty to the future of Syria <citation>https://www.csmonitor.com/World/Middle-East/2024/1202/syria-rebels-assad-aleppo-hezbollah-russia</citation><citation>https://vajiramandravi.com/upsc-daily-current-affairs/mains-articles/renewed-syrian-conflict-key-developments-and-implications-of-the-new-rebel-offensive/</citation>.
### Iran

Iran, along with Russia and Hezbollah, was a principal external backer maintaining the Assad government's frontlines prior to the November 2024 offensive <citation>https://www.csis.org/analysis/syrian-rebels-surprise-offensive-highlights-assad-regimes-weakness</citation>. The HTS-led "Deterrence of Aggression" operation was partly framed as a response to increased shelling of civilian areas by regime forces and allied Iranian militias <citation>https://rasanah-iiis.org/english/monitoring-and-translation/reports/operation-deterrence-of-aggression-in-northwestern-syria-contexts-and-perceptions/</citation>.

During the offensive, Iranian militias were directly targeted by the parallel Turkish-backed SNA "Operation Dawn of Freedom" in northern Aleppo <citation>https://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/war/op-dawn-of-freedom.htm</citation><citation>https://levant24.com/news/national/2024/11/sna-launches-dawn-of-freedom-operation/</citation>. Reports also indicated Iranian militias fought alongside Syrian government forces during the clashes for Aleppo, including at the Military Scientific Research Center <citation>https://edition.cnn.com/2024/11/29/world/syria-rebels-aleppo-war-intl/index.html</citation>.

The rapid success of the opposition offensive and the subsequent collapse of the Assad regime were seen as a significant challenge to Iran's regional influence and altered the balance of power in Syria among Iran, Russia, and Turkey <citation>https://www.osw.waw.pl/en/publikacje/analyses/2024-12-03/successful-offensive-syrian-opposition-forces-opportunity-turkey-and</citation>. The regime's vulnerability may have been exacerbated by Iran being preoccupied with other conflicts and regional tensions, particularly involving Israel and Lebanon, potentially limiting its ability to effectively support Assad <citation>https://vajiramandravi.com/upsc-daily-current-affairs/mains-articles/renewed-syrian-conflict-key-developments-and-implications-of-the-new-rebel-offensive/</citation><citation>https://www.nytimes.com/2024/11/27/world/middleeast/syria-opposition-forces-bases.html</citation>. Strategically, the capture of the Al-Bukamal border crossing in eastern Syria (initially by the SDF) disrupted a key channel previously used for Iranian weapons transfers <citation>https://medyanews.net/sdfs-seizure-of-deir-ez-zor-and-al-bukamal-alters-balance-of-power-in-the-region/</citation>. As the opposition advanced, high-level telephone discussions occurred between the leaders of Iran and Russia, and among the foreign ministers of Iran, Russia, and Turkey, reflecting diplomatic efforts to manage the escalating crisis <citation>https://www.osw.waw.pl/en/publikacje/analyses/2024-12-03/successful-offensive-syrian-opposition-forces-opportunity-turkey-and</citation>.

### Turkey

Turkey played a significant role both before and during the 2024 offensive, primarily through its support for the Syrian National Army (SNA), considered its main proxy force in northern Syria <citation>https://genesysdefense.com/intl/advancements-and-strategic-shifts-syrian-rebel-operations-in-november-2024/</citation>. Turkey maintained effective control over a northern border zone, which facilitated coordination with anti-Assad rebel groups <citation>https://www.dw.com/en/key-players-shaping-post-assad-syria/a-70996286</citation>. A key driver for Turkish involvement and backing for groups like the SNA has been its goal of preventing a powerful Kurdish military presence, represented by the Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF) and aligned groups (PKK/YPG), along the Turkish-Syrian border <citation>https://www.dw.com/en/key-players-shaping-post-assad-syria/a-70996286</citation><citation>https://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/war/op-dawn-of-freedom.htm</citation>.

As part of the Astana diplomatic process established in 2017, Turkey pursued conflicting aims compared to its partners, Russia and Iran; while Russia and Iran supported the Assad regime, Turkey backed opposition forces and maintained a military presence in northern Syria, partly to counter Kurdish autonomy aspirations <citation>https://foreignpolicy.com/2024/12/02/syria-aleppo-russia-hts-hezbollah-iran/</citation>.

Coinciding with the main HTS-led offensive, the Turkish-backed SNA launched its own distinct "Operation Dawn of Freedom" around November 29-30, 2024 <citation>https://genesysdefense.com/intl/advancements-and-strategic-shifts-syrian-rebel-operations-in-november-2024/</citation><citation>https://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/war/op-dawn-of-freedom.htm</citation><citation>https://levant24.com/news/national/2024/11/sna-launches-dawn-of-freedom-operation/</citation>. This operation explicitly targeted not only Assad regime forces and associated Iranian militias but also PKK/YPG forces (including the SDF) in areas like Tel Rifaat in the Aleppo countryside <citation>https://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/war/op-dawn-of-freedom.htm</citation><citation>https://levant24.com/news/national/2024/11/sna-launches-dawn-of-freedom-operation/</citation>. Stated aims included liberating territory, protecting civilians, enabling refugee return, and cutting PKK supply lines <citation>https://levant24.com/news/national/2024/11/sna-launches-dawn-of-freedom-operation/</citation><citation>https://www.turkiyetoday.com/region/syrian-interim-pm-operation-freedom-dawn-aims-to-cut-pkk-supply-lines-86862/</citation>. By December 1, SNA forces had captured Minnigh airbase and other locations from the YPG <citation>https://www.turkiyetoday.com/region/syrian-national-army-captures-minnigh-airbase-from-pkk-ypg-terrorist-group-in-operation-dawn-of-freedom-87120/</citation><citation>https://syria.liveuamap.com/en/2024/1-december-14-as-part-of-operation-dawn-of-freedom-opposition</citation>. Some analysts noted that the SNA's reliance on Turkey could be problematic, potentially diverting focus towards Kurdish areas rather than the Assad regime <citation>https://www.cnn.com/2024/12/02/middleeast/rebel-groups-syria-explainer-intl/index.html</citation>.

The rapid opposition gains prompted diplomatic activity, including telephone discussions among the foreign ministers of Turkey, Russia, and Iran <citation>https://www.osw.waw.pl/en/publikacje/analyses/2024-12-03/successful-offensive-syrian-opposition-forces-opportunity-turkey-and</citation>. The offensive was seen by some analysts as an opportunity for Turkey and a challenge to Russia's influence in Syria <citation>https://www.osw.waw.pl/en/publikacje/analyses/2024-12-03/successful-offensive-syrian-opposition-forces-opportunity-turkey-and</citation>.

Following the fall of the Assad government, the SNA launched a military campaign against the SDF in northern Syria, expelling them from areas like Manbij by December 10 <citation>https://www.hrw.org/world-report/2025/country-chapters/syria</citation><citation>https://rojavainformationcenter.org/2024/12/explainer-turkish-and-sna-offensive-on-manbij/</citation><citation>https://www.lemonde.fr/en/international/article/2024/12/12/syria-turkey-wants-to-extend-its-buffer-zone-by-pushing-back-kurdish-forces_6735985_4.html</citation>. Looking ahead, balancing Turkey's security concerns regarding Kurdish autonomy is considered a key challenge for post-Assad Syria <citation>https://www.swp-berlin.org/en/publication/the-political-transition-in-syria-regional-and-international-interests</citation>, with some suggesting a significant Turkish role could help manage this issue <citation>https://www.cfr.org/expert-brief/what-syrias-revived-civil-war-means-region</citation>. The United States reportedly views resolving Turkey's hostility towards the SDF, possibly through a renewed peace process with the PKK, as crucial for future stability <citation>https://www.mei.edu/publications/reimagining-syria-roadmap-peace-and-prosperity-beyond-assad</citation>.

### Ukraine

The timing and rapid success of the 2024 Syrian opposition offensive may have been influenced by external geopolitical factors, including the ongoing war in Ukraine. The collapse of the Assad regime highlighted the Syrian government's vulnerabilities, which were potentially exacerbated by the fact that its key allies, Russia and Iran, were heavily involved and preoccupied with other major conflicts, such as the war in Ukraine and heightened tensions between Israel and Hezbollah in Lebanon <citation>https://vajiramandravi.com/upsc-daily-current-affairs/mains-articles/renewed-syrian-conflict-key-developments-and-implications-of-the-new-rebel-offensive/</citation>. This diversion of resources and attention may have weakened the support structures propping up the Assad government, contributing to the conditions that allowed for the opposition's swift advance and the eventual fall of Damascus.
### Battle of Aleppo

The Battle of Aleppo refers to a major military confrontation fought between 2012 and 2016 in Aleppo, Syria's largest city and a key economic center, during the Syrian Civil War [3]. It became one of the longest and most devastating sieges in modern history and a major flashpoint in the conflict [5].

The battle began in July 2012 when Syrian rebel forces attacked the city, which had largely remained outside the initial uprising that began in 2011 [1, 2, 4]. Insurgents quickly captured several eastern districts, leading to a division of the city: the western part remained under government control, while the east was held by various opposition groups [4, 9]. The rebel forces included the Free Syrian Army (FSA) and other groups, including Islamist factions like the al-Nusra Front (later known as Jabhat Fatah al-Sham) [1, 3]. They fought against the Syrian government forces loyal to President Bashar al-Assad, who were supported by allies including Russia, Iran, and regional militias [1].

For four years, Aleppo was a key battleground, often described as "Syria's Stalingrad" due to the brutal, attritional nature of the fighting and its strategic and symbolic importance [3, 8]. The conflict within the city became a microcosm of the wider Syrian war [9]. Neither side could break the deadlock until mid-2016, when government forces, heavily supported by Russian airstrikes, besieged the rebel-held eastern sector, cutting off the last supply route [7]. The siege and subsequent offensive led to a staggering civilian toll [6].

The battle concluded in December 2016 with the withdrawal of rebel fighters and civilians from the remaining opposition-held areas under an evacuation deal [3, 7]. The Syrian government retook full control of the city, marking a significant strategic victory for President Assad in the ongoing civil war [3, 4].

### Closing offensives

As opposition forces consolidated gains in central Syria following the capture of Homs, the offensive rapidly expanded towards the capital, Damascus. A significant development occurred on December 6, 2024, when opposition groups opened a new front in southern Syria <citation>https://www.thedefensenews.com/news-details/The-Lightning-Offensive-A-Detailed-Timeline-of-Rebel-Forces-Multi-Front-Attack-on-Syria/</citation>. In Suwayda province, local Druze armed factions formed a joint operations room, attacking key government buildings like the Ba'ath Party office and police headquarters <citation>https://southfront.press/druze-fighters-clash-with-syrian-army-in-al-suwayda-videos/</citation>. Opposition groups quickly gained control of Suwayda city <citation>https://www.turkiyetoday.com/region/syrian-opposition-groups-take-control-of-suwayda-city-89741/</citation>. Concurrently, rebel forces launched an offensive in Daraa province, capturing the provincial capital, Daraa city. By midnight on December 6, these southern forces claimed control over approximately 90% of Daraa province as pro-government forces withdrew towards Damascus <citation>https://www.wikiwand.com/en/articles/Northwestern_Aleppo_offensive_(2024)</citation><citation>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/12/8/taking-syria-the-oppositions-battles-shown-in-11-maps-for-11-days</citation><citation>https://www.wikiwand.com/en/articles/2024_Syrian_opposition_offensives</citation>. Within three days, southern Syria was largely under rebel control <citation>https://www.thedefensenews.com/news-details/The-Lightning-Offensive-A-Detailed-Timeline-of-Rebel-Forces-Multi-Front-Attack-on-Syria/</citation>.

Simultaneously, other anti-Assad forces made advances in central Syria. Operating from the Al-Tanf deconfliction zone, the US-backed Syrian Free Army (SFA) captured the historic city of Palmyra (Tadmur) in Homs province between December 6-7, following the withdrawal of government troops <citation>https://www.wikiwand.com/en/articles/Northwestern_Aleppo_offensive_(2024)</citation><citation>https://webot.org/info/en/?search=Palmyra_offensive_(2024)</citation><citation>https://www.newarab.com/news/syrian-free-army-take-control-palmyra-regime-withdraws</citation><citation>https://www.yenisafak.com/en/news/us-backed-syrian-free-army-takes-control-of-homs-palmyra-district-from-regime-forces-3695430</citation>. The SFA also took control of nearby towns Al-Sukhnah and Al-Qaryatayn <citation>https://www.newarab.com/news/syrian-free-army-take-control-palmyra-regime-withdraws</citation>.

With regime defenses collapsing on multiple fronts, opposition forces rapidly closed in on Damascus. On December 8, 2024, insurgents announced they had encircled the capital and were commencing the "final stage" of their offensive <citation>https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/syria-assad-timeline-rebels-damascus-b2660853.html</citation>. Rebel fighters entered Damascus, encountering very little resistance from government forces <citation>https://www.cnn.com/2024/12/09/middleeast/timeline-syria-assad-regime-toppled-intl/index.html</citation>. Early that same day, rebels declared Damascus "liberated," marking the fall of Bashar al-Assad's government and the end of the Assad family's 54-year rule <citation>https://www.cnn.com/2024/12/09/middleeast/timeline-syria-assad-regime-toppled-intl/index.html</citation><citation>https://www.journalofdemocracy.org/articles/forever-has-fallen-the-end-of-syrias-assad/</citation>. The head of the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights reported that Bashar al-Assad had fled the country via Damascus International Airport before rebels secured it <citation>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/12/8/what-happened-in-syria-has-al-assad-really-fallen</citation>. Subsequently, the Russian Foreign Ministry confirmed Assad's resignation and announced that Russia had offered him asylum, with Russian media later reporting his presence in Moscow <citation>https://commonslibrary.parliament.uk/research-briefings/cbp-10161/</citation>.

Symbolic acts quickly followed the regime's collapse. Rebel forces claimed control of the notorious Saydnaya Military Prison north of Damascus on December 8 <citation>https://edition.cnn.com/world/live-news/syria-civil-war-12-08-2024</citation>. The Free Syrian Army flag was raised in Damascus's main square amid celebrations by residents <citation>https://edition.cnn.com/2024/12/08/middleeast/civil-war-syria-rebels-assad-intl/index.html</citation>, and visual evidence emerged showing Assad's private residence in the Malkeh district had been ransacked <citation>https://apnews.com/article/syria-assad-ousted-rebel-offensive-timeline-8c54a8b97803d4b10cde53b97227128e</citation>. The rapid fall highlighted the regime's deep-seated weaknesses, including corruption, mismanagement, reliance on foreign support (which was strained by external conflicts like the war in Ukraine), and the SAA's deterioration over years of war <citation>https://themedialine.org/top-stories/syrian-rebels-announce-fall-of-assad-regime-following-rapid-offensive/</citation><citation>https://www.19fortyfive.com/2024/12/assad-falls-why-the-syrian-army-collapsed-so-quickly/</citation><citation>https://vajiramandravi.com/upsc-daily-current-affairs/mains-articles/renewed-syrian-conflict-key-developments-and-implications-of-the-new-rebel-offensive/</citation>.




### International

Prior to the November 2024 offensive, the Syrian conflict's frontlines were largely maintained by external powers <citation>https://www.csis.org/analysis/syrian-rebels-surprise-offensive-highlights-assad-regimes-weakness</citation>. Russia and Iran, along with proxies like Hezbollah, provided crucial support to the Assad regime. Turkey backed opposition factions, particularly the Syrian National Army (SNA), maintaining a military presence in northern Syria aimed partly at curbing Kurdish autonomy along its border <citation>https://foreignpolicy.com/2024/12/02/syria-aleppo-russia-hts-hezbollah-iran/</citation><citation>https://foreignpolicy.com/2024/12/02/syria-aleppo-rebel-opposition-hts-assad-iran-turkey-russia/</citation><citation>https://www.dw.com/en/key-players-shaping-post-assad-syria/a-70996286</citation>. The United States maintained approximately 900 troops, primarily in eastern Syria <citation>https://www.brookings.edu/articles/fall-of-assad-regime-whats-next-for-syria-and-the-middle-east/</citation>, strategically positioned near routes used by Iran <citation>https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2024/12/syria-iran-russia-conflict/680847/</citation>. The Astana diplomatic process, involving Russia, Iran, and Turkey, attempted to manage these competing interests, though with conflicting goals regarding Assad's control versus opposition support and Kurdish aspirations <citation>https://foreignpolicy.com/2024/12/02/syria-aleppo-russia-hts-hezbollah-iran/</citation>.

Several international factors may have contributed to the timing and success of the opposition offensive. Russia's military focus on the war in Ukraine reportedly reduced its capacity to support Assad's forces effectively in Syria <citation>https://www.france24.com/en/middle-east/20241208-why-the-assad-regime-collapsed-in-syria-and-why-so-fast</citation><citation>https://edition.cnn.com/2024/12/07/world/syria-rebellion-middle-east-power-explainer-intl/index.html</citation>. Concurrently, some analysts suggest that Israeli actions against Hezbollah and Iranian assets in the region may have weakened these key regime allies, potentially creating an opening for the opposition <citation>https://edition.cnn.com/2024/12/07/world/syria-rebellion-middle-east-power-explainer-intl/index.html</citation><citation>https://www.nytimes.com/2024/11/27/world/middleeast/syria-opposition-forces-bases.html</citation>.

As rebel forces made rapid gains, diplomatic activity increased. Syrian President Bashar al-Assad reportedly visited Moscow, and telephone discussions occurred between the leaders of Russia and Iran, as well as among the foreign ministers of Russia, Iran, and Turkey <citation>https://www.osw.waw.pl/en/publikacje/analyses/2024-12-03/successful-offensive-syrian-opposition-forces-opportunity-turkey-and</citation>. United Nations Secretary-General Antonio Guterres called for an end to the fighting, describing the situation as resulting from a "chronic collective failure" of diplomacy <citation>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/12/5/hezbollah-backs-syrias-al-assad-as-opposition-forces-intensify-offensive</citation>.

The subsequent collapse of the Assad regime on December 8, 2024, triggered significant international reactions and shifted regional dynamics. The Russian Foreign Ministry confirmed that Assad had resigned and left Syria, announcing that Russia had offered him asylum; Russian media later reported he was in Moscow <citation>https://commonslibrary.parliament.uk/research-briefings/cbp-10161/</citation>. US President Joe Biden described the regime's fall as a "moment of historic opportunity" <citation>https://abcnews.go.com/International/syria-post-assad-power-vacuum-poses-unexpected-problems/story?id=116592032</citation>, while analysts suggested the US might seek to broker agreements involving Russia and Turkey to stabilize the situation <citation>https://www.csis.org/analysis/syrian-rebels-surprise-offensive-highlights-assad-regimes-weakness</citation>.

Turkey viewed the offensive as an opportunity, moving quickly to reopen its embassy in Damascus <citation>https://www.jordantimes.com/news/region/syria-assads-overthrow-latest-developments</citation>. Ankara's strategic aims likely included weakening Kurdish groups near its border, facilitating the return of Syrian refugees from Turkey, and strengthening its regional influence <citation>https://www.osw.waw.pl/en/publikacje/analyses/2024-12-03/successful-offensive-syrian-opposition-forces-opportunity-turkey-and</citation><citation>https://www.wilsoncenter.org/article/what-syrias-opposition-resurgence-means-ankara</citation>. Post-Assad, Turkey sought to potentially extend its buffer zone by pushing back Kurdish forces <citation>https://www.lemonde.fr/en/international/article/2024/12/12/syria-turkey-wants-to-extend-its-buffer-zone-by-pushing-back-kurdish-forces_6735985_4.html</citation>. Russia, having lost its primary ally, appeared to shift to a "damage control" policy focused on securing its military base access <citation>https://www.swp-berlin.org/en/publication/the-political-transition-in-syria-regional-and-international-interests</citation>. The fall of Damascus represented a significant setback for Iran's regional influence <citation>https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2024/12/syria-iran-russia-conflict/680847/</citation>.

The rapid regime change brought renewed global attention to Syria but also highlighted immense challenges, including the need for political transition, reconciliation, reconstruction, and addressing humanitarian needs <citation>https://vajiramandravi.com/upsc-daily-current-affairs/mains-articles/renewed-syrian-conflict-key-developments-and-implications-of-the-new-rebel-offensive/</citation><citation>https://www.swp-berlin.org/en/publication/the-political-transition-in-syria-regional-and-international-interests</citation>. International concerns arose regarding potential human rights abuses by victorious armed groups <citation>https://www.hrw.org/world-report/2025/country-chapters/syria</citation> and the risk of the Islamic State (IS) exploiting the security vacuum <citation>https://acleddata.com/2024/12/11/syria-which-groups-have-been-fighting-each-other-and-where/</citation>. The swift collapse starkly contrasted with analyses from early 2023, which had contemplated Assad's potential reintegration into the international community <citation>https://dpolitik.com/en/blog/2024/12/17/damascus-has-fallen-the-impact-of-the-offensive-in-syria/</citation>. Balancing the interests of the new Damascus authorities, Kurdish aspirations, and Turkish security concerns emerged as a key challenge for the future <citation>https://www.swp-berlin.org/en/publication/the-political-transition-in-syria-regional-and-international-interests</citation>.
### Immediate aftermath

Following the rapid capture of Aleppo in late November 2024, the Syrian military and its ally Russia launched retaliatory airstrikes against rebel forces within the city <citation>https://www.cbc.ca/news/world/syria-turkey-assad-aleppo-offensive-1.7398446</citation><citation>https://www.cbsnews.com/news/syria-war-aleppo-airstrikes-russia-assad-rebels-offensive/</citation>. The fighting caused significant disruption; Aleppo International Airport had already closed as hostilities reached residential areas, and movement in and out of the city was restricted <citation>https://www.unocha.org/publications/report/syrian-arab-republic/syria-response-displacement-aleppo-flash-update-no-02-29-november-2024</citation>. The fall of the city, however, sparked hope among Syrian refugees in Turkey, some of whom planned returns to assess the situation <citation>https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/rebels-capture-aleppo-stirs-syrian-homecoming-hopes-turkey-2024-12-05/</citation>. Inside Aleppo, residents and the new authorities began removing symbols of the Assad regime <citation>https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/c3wexlp91n4o</citation>. Hayat Tahrir al-Sham (HTS) forces reportedly made efforts to reassure local communities, including the city's Christian population, of their safety <citation>https://www.ryanjhite.com/2024/12/03/the-fall-of-aleppo-2024-a-turning-point-in-the-syrian-conflict/</citation>, although some residents feared that underlying societal divisions might persist <citation>https://www.lemonde.fr/en/international/article/2024/12/24/in-syria-s-aleppo-despite-the-fall-of-bashar-al-assad-residents-fear-that-poison-of-division-will-persist_6736401_4.html</citation>.

As rebel forces advanced south, thousands fled the city of Homs around December 6 <citation>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/12/6/thousands-flee-syrian-city-of-homs-as-rebel-fighters-close-in-war-monitor</citation>. The capture of Hama on December 5 was marked by symbolic acts, including crowds toppling a statue of former president Hafez al-Assad and the release of prisoners from Hama Central Prison <citation>https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2024/12/07/syria-assad-homs-damascus-timeline/</citation>. Images emerged showing damaged or burning government military vehicles near Hama and a defaced portrait of Bashar al-Assad on the provincial government building <citation>https://apnews.com/article/syria-assad-sweida-daraa-homs-hts-qatar-7f65823bbf0a7bd331109e8dff419430</citation><citation>https://projects.voanews.com/syria/timeline/</citation>.

The offensive culminated in the fall of Damascus on December 8, 2024. Rebel forces entered the capital facing little resistance and declared it "liberated," ending the Assad family's 54-year rule <citation>https://www.cnn.com/2024/12/09/middleeast/timeline-syria-assad-regime-toppled-intl/index.html</citation><citation>https://www.journalofdemocracy.org/articles/forever-has-fallen-the-end-of-syrias-assad/</citation>. Reports indicated Bashar al-Assad had fled the country via Damascus airport shortly before the city fell <citation>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/12/8/what-happened-in-syria-has-al-assad-really-fallen</citation>; the Russian Foreign Ministry later announced he had resigned and been granted asylum in Russia <citation>https://commonslibrary.parliament.uk/research-briefings/cbp-10161/</citation>. In Damascus, residents celebrated in the streets, the Free Syrian Army flag was raised in a main square, and Assad's private residence was reportedly ransacked <citation>https://www.nytimes.com/2024/12/08/world/middleeast/syria-damascus-assad-fall.html</citation><citation>https://edition.cnn.com/2024/12/08/middleeast/civil-war-syria-rebels-assad-intl/index.html</citation><citation>apnews.com/article/syria-assad-ousted-rebel-offensive-timeline-8c54a8b97803d4b10cde53b97227128e</citation>. Rebel forces also claimed control of the notorious Saydnaya Military Prison north of the capital <citation>edition.cnn.com/world/live-news/syria-civil-war-12-08-2024</citation>. HTS leader Abu Mohammad al-Golani delivered a speech from Damascus promising inclusivity and safety for minorities <citation>https://www.brookings.edu/articles/fall-of-assad-regime-whats-next-for-syria-and-the-middle-east/</citation><citation>https://abcnews.go.com/International/syria-post-assad-power-vacuum-poses-unexpected-problems/story?id=116592032</citation>.

The rapid escalation severely impacted the humanitarian situation, with an estimated 178,000 people displaced by early December and many aid organizations suspending operations in Aleppo <citation>https://www.acaps.org/fileadmin/Data_Product/Main_media/20241206_ACAPS_Briefing_note_Syria_escalation_of_conflict_in_the_northwest.pdf</citation>. UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres called the escalating conflict a result of a "chronic collective failure" of diplomacy <citation>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/12/5/hezbollah-backs-syrias-al-assad-as-opposition-forces-intensify-offensive</citation>, while UN envoy Geir Pedersen urged dialogue <citation>https://www.npr.org/2024/12/07/g-s1-37354/syrian-government-appears-to-have-fallen-in-stunning-end-to-long-rule-of-assad-family</citation>. Internationally, US President Joe Biden called the regime's fall a "fundamental act of justice" but also a "moment of risk" <citation>https://apnews.com/article/trump-syria-biden-ukraine-russia-putin-assad-cbb3ad1fe14ccd32452aa118140e23cf</citation>, while Turkey reopened its embassy in Damascus <citation>https://www.jordantimes.com/news/region/syria-assads-overthrow-latest-developments</citation>. In the immediate aftermath, the new authorities began uncovering and seizing large quantities of Captagon linked to the former regime, exposing manufacturing sites and smuggling networks <citation>https://ctc.westpoint.edu/the-new-syrian-governments-fight-against-the-islamic-state-hezbollah-and-captagon/</citation>. However, reports also emerged of human rights abuses committed by non-state armed groups during the offensive, and the widespread presence of landmines and explosive remnants of war posed an ongoing lethal threat to civilians <citation>https://www.hrw.org/world-report/2025/country-chapters/syria</citation><citation>https://www.hrw.org/news/2025/04/08/syria-landmines-explosive-remnants-harming-civilians</citation>.
